On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 22:27, Mike Bresnahan wrote:
> A problem that I am very often faced with is writing some code that
> interacts with a 3rd party API which I am unfamiliar with.  In these
cases
> it seems counter productive to create unit tests for my own code when
I have
> no idea whether my code will actually work when used with the 3rd
party API.
> I could end up wasting a lot time writing and testing code that is
designed
> incorrectly.  In these cases, it seems more sensical to me to write
> integration tests which involve both my code and the 3rd party API. 
How do
> people more familiar with unit testing handle such situations?

That's how I deal with it.

FYI: The project I am currently working on has 70 or 80 "integration"
tests that run with the other 2100+ programmer tests every time we check
in code.  Every programmer runs the tests before they check in,
religiously.  We usually check-in at a minimum of three or four times
daily.  The programmer tests run in about 100 seconds, the integration
tests run in about 225 seconds.  We are checking 3rd party code,
services, the server environment, etc. every time we check in.  It's
heavenly!

-- 
Jason Rogers
